I did not realise. I would never have harmed your Majesty.
It's no excuse. I will hear no more. Where are my men?
Wait! Please, your Majesty. There is one more thing you must know. Lady Sarah, you're pregnant, aren't you?
With my great-great-grandfather.
You are with child?
Yes, your Majesty. Oh, your Majesty, I beg you, spare the life of my baby.
I don't believe the Queen could kill a child.
Your life is spared, Sarah, but only for the sake of the child growing
inside me that I could not destroy another, bastard or no.
And my husband?
You have received a favour you do not deserve in your own life. You dare to ask me to grant more than that?
No.
As for you, you will be taken to prison at once.
Your Majesty, may I make a suggestion?
Well, Doctor?
Your sister, the Lady Elizabeth, is under house arrest. Let Lady Sarah join her in her imprisonment. She can attend her there.
Very well.
And I'm sure Monsieur de Noailles will be happy to arrange the matter for you. I believe he is well acquainted with the Lady Elizabeth's position.
Ah. Of course. If your Majesty desires it.
See to it. Now go, all of you. I have no mind to think on these events further.
Your Majesty. Come with me, girl.
My son shall be named after you, good Doctor.
Your Majesty.
Go, Doctor. Even you.
Come on, Evelyn.
Footsteps recede.
Guard!
Your Majesty.
I want to see Thomas Smith. Now.
Street.
We just saved her life! Nothing like gratitude, is there?

She's scared, Evelyn. Someone close to her nearly succeeded in killing her. She's going to be terrified of plots for the rest of her life. She can't trust anyone. Her husband has no interest in her, and she's pinning all her hope on a baby that I think she knows deep down she doesn't have. Under the circumstances, I'm prepared to forgive her for being a bit brusque.

I suppose you're right. Well, I have to say I'm surprised it wasn't de Noailles who was doing the poisoning. But then I suppose that would have mucked up history too. He becomes the French Ambassador later on, you know.
Really? Well, history's back on its right lines now. You and your ancestors, you'll all be fine.
Sure?
Well, it all fits in with your history books, doesn't it? Mother attending Elizabeth in captivity, father executed by Queen Mary.
Burnt to death. What a horrific way to go, even if he was extremely objectionable.
Hmm. And John Whiteside-Smith just waiting to be born.
And to become Elizabeth's advisor.
Yes. Now you come to mention it, I do seem to have some vague memories of some John chap at Elizabeth's Court. Funny that.
Zip sound.
Well, there's only one way to find out if it's all sorted.
Hmm?
Switch this off. Your gizmo thing.
Very well.
Powers down.
Ah. Fine. Absolutely fine. Not a twinge.
Good. Well, I think that proves you're safe now.
I might be safe, but what about everyone else?
I'm sorry?
William Leaf and George Crow. They'll be executed, won't they.
I'm afraid so.

George Crow's got a wife and family. William Leaf, he's just a child, Doctor, and with such a sweet smile. He reminded me of one of my students. I promised him he'd be all right. They're good men. They don't deserve to die.
I know. But if it's part of history
It isn't!
You don't know that.
Yes, I do. I'm getting a headache again. History isn't quite back on the right track yet, I'm sure of it. An! We have to save them. (groans)
All right, all right, we'll go.
But how are we going to get back into the Tower? The Warder won't fall for the same trick twice. Actually, how are we going to get to the Tower at all? Can you face the river again?
Why worry about water when you've got a Time and Space machine just down the road?
I'd rather jog back and risk my knees.
Nonsense. I'm extremely good at short hops. Come on.
Thomas Smith, your Majesty.
The traitor.
(frightened) Your Majesty, forgive me.
You ask me for mercy now yout life is forfeit? When you have plotted against me, corrupted my lady in waiting for your ungodly pleasures, practised heresy?
Your Majesty, I swear my allegiance to you. From now on I will be your most loyal subject.
It will not save you! You are guilty of treason. You plotted against my life!
I was misguided, your Majesty. Spare me. See, already I have proved my loyalty. I gave information on those who plotted against you.
The Doctor?
Yes.
The Doctor was no traitor.
But. Your Majesty, if there is anything I can do.
You would save others from your fate?
Yes.
Then there is something you can do.
Anything.

Before you die, you will recant. You will tell the other followers of your heretical teachings that they are wrong, that their way leads only to suffering. That if they embrace the true religion, they will be saved. Well? You will be saving their souls!
No.
What?

I will not do it. It is not your religion that is true, it is mine. You are the heretic, not me, not Leaf or Crow or any Protestant. I may burn, but the Lord will take me to his side, and I will not lead any man from the path of righteousness!
How dare you! Get him out of my sight! You will burn for this!
Come on.
Footsteps recede.
May God have mercy on your soul.
Raven caws.
They say we'll go to hell, George Crow.
What do they know? It's the Queen and her like that'll be for any eternal suffering that's going, William Leaf.
Crow, why didn't God send an angel to save us, like he did with Daniel in the lion's den?
We ain't here to question God's ways, William Leaf. Reckon he wants to meet us close to, tell us what a good job we've been doing. Reckon we'll be what they call martyrs.
What's that, then?

Well, that's when people look at us and say, they could have been Catholic, like what the Queen said, but they got burnt instead. That Protestant stuff must be really good stuff if people be burnt for it, they'll say.

Don't fool yourself, George Crow. They won't say that. They'll come to watch us burn, then they'll go home and think no more of it, sept to wonder when they'll next get a day out like that. I know I would. And anyway, Crow, I don't want to be a martyr. I don't want to die.
Leaf cries as the Tardis materialises.
God save us. What is wrong with us, Leaf? The hounds of Hell are coming for us.
Tardis door opens.
Mistress Evelyn!
Oh, you poor boy. Come here.
Then you're killed already.
What do you mean?
You must have died, and God sent your soul back to Earth to take us to Heaven when we're killed too.
No, that's not it. I'm still very much alive.
You're not an angel, then?
An angel in a cardigan? Well, I've seen stranger things.
Doctor? What are you doing here?
Well, if you'll excuse the expression, we've come to take you away from all this.
I don't understand.
I don't either, really. Don't worry about it.
It's more witchcraft, then?
I told you, William, that there's no such thing. We've come to rescue you, that's all.
We're not to be martyrs?
There'll be martyrs enough in England, George, though I'd happily save all of them.
You know that's not possible, Evelyn.
I know. I'll make do with these two.
We're really not going to die?
No. No, you're not.
But the Queen
I was thinking of one of the free Protestant cities. Geneva, perhaps, or Frankfurt?
We can't afford to go there.
You just leave it all to me.
But it'll be all foreign.
A lot of Protestant exiles ended up there, I believe.
Well, I reckon that'd be all right, then. Come on, William Leaf. Pull yourself together.
Leave him be, George. Boys can cry too, you know.
I weren't crying.
It doesn't matter. Come on, the Doctor's going to take you somewhere safe.
Away from England?
Oh, you'll be able to return in a few year's time.
How'd you know?
We just arrived in a box that appeared out of thin air. You saw that with your own eyes. Let's assume we know what's going to happen. You can call it magic, if it helps.
But not witchcraft.
All right, then. What does happen?
Can we tell them?
Under the circumstances, yes, I think so.
Well, Mary isn't pregnant. You know that already. And she never will be, although she'll think she is a few more times right up to her death.
She's gonna die? Soon?
November 1558. Then Elizabeth becomes Queen, and within a few months everything's changed. The Spanish alliance, the restoration of Catholicism, gone for good.
Praise the Lord for that!
And if you decide to come back to England then, well, in about twenty years time, look up a chap called John Whiteside-Smith.
I think it's time we were going, Evelyn. Before the warders come round? Come on, into the Tardis, everyone.
The Tardis? What about my family?
I don't think we can
Oh, please, Doctor.
Oh, very well. We'll pick them up on our way.
Come on, William. It's going to be a bit of a shock for you, I expect, but don't let it worry you. I didn't. And try to forget about England, and Mary.
Your Majesty, if I might just
Get out! I will see nobody! Stay. Are you with the Doctor? Has he returned to see me?
No, your Majesty. Monsieur le Docteur has left.
Then leave me!
But I was wondering if I might
Go!
Your Majesty.
Footsteps recede. Door opens and closes.
Oh, Doctor, what is to become of me? Am I truly doing the right thing? If it wasn't for my child. Oh Lord, thank you for giving me this child.
Tardis in flight.
There. They should be all right now. And your headache seems seems to have vanished finally.
Er, yes. It has.
Hmm.
Anyway, no more Bloody Mary for them. They can come back when a rea/ Queen is on the throne.
Mary did a lot of good things in her reign, you know. She wasn't a
bad person. She was kind and thoughtful towards those who knew her. She was just an idealist.
Oh, you're right. She was an idealist and a fanatic. And people like that are dangerous in power.
I understood her.
She was willing to kill for her beliefs, and that's not good for a country, especially when other people are willing to die for theirs.
They were willing to kill, too. Sometimes its unavoidable.
You've killed people for what you believe in?
I've caused people to die. I don't know if that's the same thing. (sighs) I like to think it isn't.
I'd like to think that too, because if I didn't, I wouldn't want to travel with you any more.
You wouldn't what? I think you'll find you're going straight back home.
Oh no, I'm not. I'm a historian. This is a Time machine. You can take me anywhere, and I'll still be home in time for tea. After all, I haven't even met Elizabeth yet.
I'm surprised you're not sick of the Tudors by now.
Oh, no. But do you know what the worst part of that whole business was?
Being threatened with imminent execution?
Finding out I'm descended from a pompous priest and a pathetic male-dependant wimp of a girl. Still
At least it wasn't me? What that what you were going to say?
Oh, I never believed that for a second. I could never be related to someone with your dress sense.
Oh, you're too kind.
Ah, nobody's perfect.
Speak for yourself.
Huh. You can't even pilot this ship properly.
I can take you anywhere in Space and Time.
Can you? That's a bargain, then.
All right. Elizabeth's Court?
Not just yet. Let's stop off somewhere where they understand chocolate. After all that, I think we could do with a nice, relaxing cup of cocoa. Made with milk. Where do you suggest? Mexico?
I'm not really sure.
And if I could get hold of some chocolate, I could make you one of my famous chocolate cakes, to say thank you, you know.
(swallows hard) Well, I suppose a nice slice of cake wouldn't go amiss.
Excellent!
I do hope I don't regret this.

GUARD: Doctor John Smith?
DOCTOR: Yes?
GUARD: You are under arrest for heresy.
DOCTOR: I'm what?
GUARD: You have wittingly disobeyed the Queen's instructions with regard to the practice of worship.
DOCTOR: Poppycock.
GUARD: We have the testimony of Thomas Smith, a known Protestant priest, who was arrested a short while ago. He has named you as his co-conspirator in a wilful plot to deny the one true religion.
DOCTOR: Well, who's Thomas Smith? I've never met the man.
EVELYN: He must mean the Reverend Thomas. Everyone's a Smith round here.
DOCTOR: Well, it is the most common name in this country. That's why I chose it.
GUARD: Neighbours report a man and woman of your companion's description leaving his house this morning.
DOCTOR: But you can't arrest a man for talking to people who may have been leaving someone else's house. Oh, this is all nonsense.
GUARD: Do you deny that you have never attended Mass in this parish?
DOCTOR: No, I don't deny that.
GUARD: Yet it is the Queen's express wish that all should attend.
DOCTOR: But I've only just arrived in the parish.
GUARD: Then perhaps you could give me the name of the priest in the parish where you usually hear Mass.
DOCTOR: This is ridiculous. Look, we have to see the Queen. It's urgent.
GUARD: You're not going to see anyone. You're all coming with us.
DOCTOR: To where?
GUARD: To the Tower.
DOCTOR: The Tower?
LEAF: No! Mistress Evelyn.
EVELYN: It'll be all right, William, I promise.
DOCTOR: You can't keep us in the Tower.
GUARD: Don't worry, you won't be there long.
DOCTOR: Well, good.
GUARD: Yes, under the new law, heretics will be burnt at the stake.
DOCTOR: You have to listen to me. You can't burn me at the stake. I know about a plot to kill the Queen.
GUARD: You know about a plot to kill the Queen?
DOCTOR: Yes.
GUARD: If you're telling the truth
DOCTOR: Which I always do.
GUARD: Then you're right, we won't burn you at the stake.
DOCTOR: Good.
GUARD: You're likely to be beheaded instead.
DOCTOR: What?
EVELYN: The Tower of London. The actual Tower of London. I've been here before, of course, but it wasn't quite the same. More glass display cases last time I was here, you know. And tour guides getting under your feet all the time, and trying to move you on when you're trying to examine something properly so a load of historically ignorant tourists can make jokes about the size of the King's balls.
DOCTOR: Well, I hope you're enjoying this tourist preview. Feel free to examine whatever you like. These stone walls, for example. Those chairs. Or this locked door. Or. No. No, I think you'll find that's everything. You know, last time I was here was when I was visiting Lady Jane Grey. Hmm. Maybe I'd better not mention that to Queen Mary. She might not be too impressed.
EVELYN: No, I wouldn't have thought so. And we wouldn't want to upset the Queen, would we? She might have us thrown in the Tower.
DOCTOR: We have to find a way of warning the Queen that her life may be in danger.
EVELYN: Yes, after all she's done for us.
DOCTOR: You, Doctor Smythe, have to learn the responsibility of time travel. Mary shouldn't die until November 1558. It is now January 1555. If she's killed now, history will be changed, and you will cease to exist, so we have to save her life.
EVELYN: Well, there's only one thing to do then, isn't there?
DOCTOR: And what would that be?
EVELYN: Well, escape, of course.
DOCTOR: Ah, thank you, Doctor Smythe. I should never have thought of that. Oh, the Queen's as good as saved.
EVELYN: No need to be sarcastic. We just have to think of a plan, that's all. We could pick the lock.
DOCTOR: And you can do that, can you?
EVELYN: Yes, actually.
DOCTOR: Really?
EVELYN: Found it very handy over the years.. Student parties, you know. They go on to all hours and the porters do hate being called out in the middle of the night when you've forgotten your keys. All it needs is a hairpin.
DOCTOR: And you happen to have such a thing on you?
EVELYN: As a matter of fact, I do. Lucky they didn't confiscate my bag, really.
DOCTOR: I see. You are, without a doubt, one of the most well-prepared and useful companions with whom I have ever travelled.
EVELYN: Thank you.
DOCTOR: It's just a shame that the door is held in place by a staple and toggle on the outside. Excellent though your skills may be, you can't pick a metal rod.
EVELYN: Ah. No. Well, perhaps there's a secret passage?
DOCTOR: In all your years of studying this period, did you ever hear of anyone escaping from the Tower of London through a secret passage?
EVELYN: Well, no.
DOCTOR: I admit that isn't conclusive proof as to non-existence of such an exit, but it is a fairly strong indication.
EVELYN: Well, you think of something, then.
DOCTOR: Well, if you give me a moment's peace, instead of wittering on about hair pins and secret passages, I fully intend to.
EVELYN: I could pretend to be ill, and then when a guard comes along, you hit him over the head with that chair
DOCTOR: (sighs) Violence is never the answer. Brains above brawn every time, that's how I do things.
EVELYN: But you're not doing anything. The Queen could be dead. If I didn't have your gizmo, I might have vanished completely by now.
DOCTOR: Actually, if history had changed that much, I'm not sure if my gizmo would be strong enough to protect you.
EVELYN: Oh, wonderful.
DOCTOR: It means the Queen is probably still alive, that we still have a chance.
EVELYN: Hmm. I can't tell you how worried I was when I vanished before. I thought I'd gone for good. If it wasn't for the Reverend Thomas bringing my bag back.
DOCTOR: Yes. I suppose you should be very grateful they were trying to set you up, this Thomas and de Noailles.
EVELYN: Oh yes, very grateful.
DOCTOR: The point is, they didn't succeed. And this is a much better situation than if we'd been arrested then.
EVELYN: How? We're locked in a small, smelly cell in the Tower of London.
DOCTOR: But if the Queen had believed you were trying to poison her, that would be it. She is the ultimate law. If we can see her, if we can save her life, she will undoubtedly let us go.
EVELYN: Let me get this straight. If we can get out of the Tower to see the
EVELYN: Queen, the Queen will let us out of the Tower.
DOCTOR: Yes.
EVELYN: Huh.
DOCTOR: If we could work out what their plan is, that would help.
EVELYN: So you don't think they're really planning to just walk in with a bomb, then.

EVELYN: But how?

EVELYN: Oh dear.
DOCTOR: If we could just work out how they intend to administer it

DOCTOR: It's a chance.
EVELYN: Won't they just say we must be part of the plot if we know the details?
DOCTOR: My dear Evelyn, you obviously haven't heard how persuasive I can be.
EVELYN: No, you're right, I haven't.
DOCTOR: Hmm. Now, poison. Ingested, I would think. Contact poison is very rare.
EVELYN: But it won't be in her food or drink. She has tasters.
DOCTOR: True.
EVELYN: Unless she has a glass of water by her bed. I always keep one there in case I wake up in the night a bit parched.
DOCTOR: You forget, they don't drink the water here. Anyway, there'd be no guarantee that one of the ladies in waiting who share her bed wouldn't drink any night time beverage instead. So not them. What else might the Queen do?
EVELYN: According to William and George, she does nothing but go to Mass.
DOCTOR: Yes, well, William and George are understandably biased on the religious front. But that could be it. She goes to Mass
EVELYN: And takes the sacraments.

DOCTOR: Yes.

DOCTOR: Evelyn? Oh no, it's happened!

WARDER: Let me see.

DOCTOR: What? Oh.
DOCTOR: Oh, sorry about that. I really thought you were ill.

DOCTOR: There we are, the Palace of Whitehall.

DOCTOR: Let me help you up.

EVELYN: Just watch me.

EVELYN: I'm afraid I didn't pack a towel. Perhaps you could shake yourself out like a dog.

QUEEN: The Doctor?
THOMAS: Yes.

QUEEN: Then there is something you can do.

LEAF: But the Queen

DOCTOR: You just leave it all to me.
